Award.AwardTitle: Graduate Workshop in Algebraic Geometry for Women and Mathematicians of Minority Genders
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the Graduate Workshop in Algebraic Geometry for Women and Mathematicians of Minority Genders which will take place at MIT and Harvard University over the weekend of February 17-18, 2018. The workshop will promote the professional community of women and researchers of minority genders in algebraic geometry and adjacent fields, focusing on the needs of young graduate students. Participants will be exposed to the research of leading women algebraic geometers and will have the opportunity to interact with faculty and postdoc mentors and with each other. Attending this conference will boost participants' feelings of 'knowing people' at other, non-gender-specific conferences, and therefore it will have lasting effects on the community beyond this workshop. More information can be found at the workshop website, https://sites.google.com/view/gwag.

Participants will gain insight into rapidly advancing topics in algebraic geometry through minicourses by invited speakers on Coleman integration on curves, conformal blocks vector bundles, moduli spaces of tropical and algebraic curves, and irrationality of higher-dimensional varieties. Afternoon working groups will delve deeper into these topics by working through explicit examples and open-ended problems under the guidance of a mentor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ‘Graduate Workshop in Algebraic Geometry for Women and Mathematicians of Minority Genders’ (GWAGWMMG) took place at MIT and Harvard over the weekend of February 17-18, 2018, organized by Rohini Ramadas and Isabel Vogt, with faculty support from Bjorn Poonen and Gigliola Staffilani. In total, the workshop attracted 65-70 participants working in or near algebraic geometry.  The award was used to support participant travel.

The workshop was organized around four mini-courses by leading women algebraic geometers at different career stages: Professors Jennifer Balakrishnan, Melody Chan, Angela Gibney and Brooke Ullery. These morning lectures introduced the diverse cohort of graduate students to new frontiers in algebraic geometry, highlighting directions of future study. The lectures were complemented by TA-led afternoon sessions where small groups of participants worked on explicit examples and problems contributed by a morning speaker.

Participants indicated in anonymous feedback that the workshop was one of the most supportive conference environments they had experienced and that the problem sessions provided a unique opportunity to work with other women. Of the 42 participants who completed the survey, 100% indicated strong interest in attending similar workshops in the future.  This workshop enhanced connections in this community and will jumpstart future meetings of young women and minority-gender algebraic geometers, in part through infrastructure created to make such opportunities known to participants.
